Project #1

Summary

My honours project for the final year of my degree was an interesting deep dive into how radio frequencies transmitted from car key fobs can be manipulated and exploited to gain unauthorised access to the vehicle. The project allowed me to experiment with both hardware and software.

Solution

Rolling codes, also known as hopping codes, are a security feature used in wireless communication systems such as car key fobs and garage door openers. They work by using an algorithm to generate a unique code each time a device is activated, which is different from the previous code. This prevents an attacker from intercepting and replaying the same code to gain unauthorized access to the system.

The solution I implemented is known as a Jam-Listen-Replay attack. This type of attack utilises a signal jammer which blocks the signal being successfully transmitted from the key fob to the car. While the signal is being jammed, the capturing device is recording the signals being transmitted to the vehicle. Once the signal jammer has been turned off, the car key will work again, although when the attacker returns they can simply replay the recorded signal and gain unauthorised access since the recorded signal has never been seen by the car.

Skills Used

  • Raspberry Pi
  • Raspberry Pi OS
  • Linux
  • Arduino
  • Radio Spectrum
  • SDR Sharp
  • Signal Amplification
  • Hardware Soldering

  • Network Management
